summary: The U.S. District Court for the Western District of Kentucky today entered a final judgment in favor of a Kentucky-based company and its employee in connection with a July 1, 2012 car crash that left four injured passengers with broken jaw and required emergency medical treatment.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Louisville, Kentucky, alleges that the trial court improperly excluded the testimony of an expert witness who had been injured in the crash and failed to instruct the jury as to whether he was entitled to punitive damages.  According to the complaint, Zewoldi's expert testimony, which was contemporaneous with the facts of the case, was untimely and unrecorded.  In addition, the complaint alleges that Bryant passed out forms to the passengers shortly after the crash.  As alleged in the SEC's order, Bryant passed these forms out in the aftermath of the crash, showing that the expert witness had not acted in a negligent manner.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the court's judgment, Bryant consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins him from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and orders him to pay disgorgement and prejudgment interest in the amount of $1,038, and a civil penalty of $100,000.  On March 12, 2015, the court issued a scheduling order that set the matter for trial on Monday, March 2, 2015.  A hearing on the matter was scheduled for March 13, 2015 and the case was rescheduled for March 16, 2015 for a later date.   The complaint also alleges that, in exercising its discretion, it improperly excluded certain documents from introduction, including testimony from one of Bryant's co-defendants, and in denying a motion for a continuance of the trial on January 14, 2015 (Ky. App. 2010).  In a parallel action, the Kentucky Attorney General's Office today announced that it has filed an emergency action to halt the pending litigation against Bryant and his company, Kentucky Milk Marketing and Antimonopoly Comm. Ltd. (KMGTC).  The court's order also issued an order temporarily suspending Bryant from appearing or practicing before the SEC as an attorney, and ordering him to sign a civil injunctive proceeding against the defendants.  This order temporarily prohibits him from participating in the issuance, purchase, offer, or sale of any medical records, including those of a licensed physician, and requires him to provide written testimony in the course of the litigation.  Finally, the Court issued a temporary restraining order against Bryant, prohibiting him from
